text: Family Member: Oh. Doctor: However you want to bill it and put it in a nice package, anything you take is a potential drug swirling around in your bloodstream. Family Member: Hm Mmm. Or make it worse. Patient: Well then you mentioned other supplements. Doctor: Right. I think your standard basic multivitamin, it’s a thumbs up. Because that’s just sort of your regular, you know, recommended daily allowance, your recommended daily intake, that’s no problem. Patient: That’s the macular- Family Member: For macular degeneration? Patient: Yeah.

text: Family Member: So, um, we’ve had a little bit of a (pause) Doctor: So, so, well, here, here’s - I have lack of flexibility. So, again, I can only see you on Tuesdays. Family Member: Got it. text: Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream – Patient: Okay, but -- Doctor: To get control. We’re fixing it here, but the rest of you is not controlled. Doctor: Okay? Hi!!! Patient: So. So. Doctor: We’re having all sorts of discussion! Healthcare Professional 2: Really?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So often we think of bone as being, we have this sort of feeling that bone is worse, but mostly because we just have trouble imaging and seeing how it changes. So, uh, but it also affects some of the trials we have because those trials require biopsies of tumor tissue, and it’s really hard to get tumor tissue from the bone. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So it may alter what we can do in terms of trials. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So today, I thought we could talk a little bit about kind of what the standard things are to do next, and then we could talk a little bit about some trials that we have. The typical thing we would do next is either to put you on another hormone- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so you’d be on the shot and a pill. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, we talked before about there’s a drug called, Zytiga, and a drug called, Xtandi. Uh, they both could, could work very well, uh, and they’re both associated with improving survival in men who get the drugs. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The main side effect of both is fatigue. Patient: Um hum.

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And so half the people get it, half the people don’t- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: but you still have to come in and get an infusion three times a week. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And so that one is logistically pretty tough. But that is something that you know if we’re going chemotherapy, I can make sure we get you the permission slip or the consent form to let you know what that would look like. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may, I don’t think we have an opening at Hospital B but that’s one of the sites that we collaborate with, and I think they had interest in opening it, and so we can check in to see whether they have that open. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But that would be clearly if we say I’m doing chemotherapy, do I want to do something more on top of it, so that would be one option. Experimentally we have two treatments, uh one based on the fact that your ARV7 is positive. We have an experimental study where we give everyone immune therapy, a doublet. That is a combination of two drugs that are approved in melanoma, soon to be approved in kidney cancer that can turn on your immune system to attack your cancer. It doesn’t work all that well so far in prostate cancer, maybe fifteen percent of people may get a benefit. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
